name: Lotus
rituals: Daily offerings - fresh lotus to Buddha images
Vesak celebrations - lotus lamps floated on water
Visualization - opening thousand-petaled crown chakra lotus
Funeral rites - lotus symbolizes rebirth in Pure Land

colorSymbolism.red: Compassion, love, passion, heart chakra, Avalokiteshvara
colorSymbolism.blue: Wisdom, knowledge, victory over senses, Manjushri
colorSymbolism.pink: Supreme lotus, Buddha himself, historical Buddha
colorSymbolism.white: Mental and spiritual purity, Bodhi (perfect enlightenment)

symbolicMeanings: Roots in mud = grounded in reality of suffering
Stem through water = journey through samsara
Flower above water = enlightenment transcending worldly attachment
Lotus closes at night, opens at dawn = death and rebirth cycle
sacredSignificance: Central symbol of Buddhism. Buddha born with lotus appearing at each step. Lotus throne represents transcendence. Emergence from mud = enlightenment possible despite samsara. Pure Land Buddhism: rebirth in lotus of Amitabha's paradise.
safetyWarnings: generally safe as food and tea
ensure clean water source if wild-harvesting
preparationMethods: Lotus seed tea: simmer dried seeds for calming nervousness
Lotus root: slice and cook for nutrition and lung health
Lotus petal tea: steep dried petals for aromatic calming tea
Stamens: dry and use in tea blends for heart health
Seed paste: grind seeds for mooncake filling (spiritual festivals)
uses: Buddha statues - seated on lotus throne (padmasana)
Mantra visualization - Om Mani Padme Hum (jewel in the lotus)
Meditation - contemplate lotus emergence from mud as path metaphor
Temple offerings - fresh lotus flowers offered daily
Iconography - lotus held by bodhisattvas symbolizes compassion
culturalContext: Every part of lotus used: seeds (longevity), roots (nutrition), petals (beauty), stamens (tea). Lotus ponds essential at Buddhist temples. Ancient symbol predating Buddhism, adopted and elevated by dharma.
description: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening in Buddhism. It grows from mud yet remains unstained, representing the potential for enlightenment within samsara. Different colored lotuses carry distinct spiritual meanings.
